raw.author: Chaucer
contexts: Chaucer is a medieval poet specializing mainly in romance, whether sacred or secular.
This state of things makes it difficult to appraise a literature which includes Chaucer, much of whose poetry is translated or paraphrased from others;
Chaucer’s monk, who clearly understood what he was doing, began with Lucifer and Adam, and we may be well advised to follow his example.
Similarly the epilogue to Chaucer’s Troilus puts a Courtly Love tragedy into its historical relation to “payens corsed olde rites.”

Chaucer represents himself as a shy, demure, inconspicuous member of his pilgrimage, agreeing politely with everybody (“And I seyde his opinion was good”), and showing to the pilgrims none of the powers of observation that he displays to his reader.

We have an indication that there is no consistent sound-pattern when there are two equally satisfactory versions of the same poem differing in texture, as in the Prologue to Chaucer’s Legend of Good Women.
Examples include The Owl and the Nightingale, Chaucer’s Parliament of Fowls, and Spenser’s Mutability Cantos.

raw.author: William Blake
contexts: the prophecies of Blake

"Every poem must necessarily be a perfect unity," says Blake: this, as the wording implies, is not a statement of fact about all existing poems, but a statement of the hypothesis which every reader adopts in first trying to comprehend even the most chaotic poem ever written.
“Exuberance is beauty,” said Blake.
Blake himself was willing to define poetry as “allegory addressed to the intellectual powers.”
"The desire of man being infinite," said Blake, "the possession is infinite and himself infinite."

Blake’s Prophetic Books represent one of the few successful efforts to tackle conversational rhythm in verse—so successful that many critics are still wondering if they are “real poetry.” Blake’s view that a longer line than the pentameter was needed to represent educated colloquial speech in verse may be compared with the experiments of Clough and Bridges in hexameters, which are also attempts to capture the same kind of rhythm, though at least in Clough one feels that a strict adherence to the metre gives a somewhat roller-coaster quality to the accent.
the poet-painter Blake, whose engraved lyrics are in the emblem tradition, has a role in the lyric analogous to that of the poet-composers Campion and Dowland on the musical side.
The proverbs in Blake’s Marriage of Heaven and Hell are parody-proverbs, written from the oracular or epiphanic point of view.

Most unqualified poems of joy are associated with some kind of innocent vision, as in Blake: the great Epicurean poets, from Horace to Herrick, accept the limitations of joy in experience, its transience in an abyss of “endless night.”
commentaries: The author references Blake's prophecies as examples of mythological epics representing psychological states in the Romantic period.
The author quotes Blake to present the critical hypothesis that a reader must assume a poem's unity as a starting point for comprehension.
The author quotes Blake's statement 'Exuberance is beauty' to support the argument about the nature of artistic effect and catharsis.
The author cites Blake's definition of poetry as 'allegory addressed to the intellectual powers' to connect the discussion of exuberance with intellectual allegory.
The author quotes Blake to support the idea that human desire is infinite and apocalyptic.
The author discusses William Blake's Prophetic Books as a successful effort to use conversational rhythm in verse and references Blake's view on line length.
The author mentions Blake as a poet-painter whose engraved lyrics belong to the emblem tradition, comparing his role in lyric to that of musical composers.
The author describes the proverbs in Blake's 'Marriage of Heaven and Hell' as parody-proverbs, contrasting them with secular proverbs by adopting an oracular viewpoint.
The author references Blake as an example of poets whose poems of joy are associated with an innocent vision, contrasting with Epicurean poets like Horace and Herrick.

goodreads_match.description: The Frogs tells the story of the god Dionysus, despairing of the state of Athens' tragedians, and allegedly recovering from the disastrous Battle of Arginusae. commentaries: The author cites Hooker to further argue that human desire naturally seeks a higher, infinite fulfillment.

goodreads_match.title: Ion
goodreads_match.description: One of Euripides' late plays, Ion tells the story of Kreousa, queen of Athens, and her son by the god Apollo. Apollo raped Kreousa; she secretly abandoned their child, assuming thereafter that the god had allowed him to die. Ion, however, is saved to become a ward of Apollo's temple at Delphi. In the play, Kreousa and her husband Xouthos go to Delphi to seek a remedy for their childlessness; Apollo, speaking through his oracle, gives Ion to Xouthos as a son, enraging the apparently still childless Kreousa.....
